speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Decision Making
text: And it's not bad because it's not well-intentioned, but it's bad because it's not contextual. So when someone tells you to quit your job and chase your dreams, or they tell you to sit tight and grind through and build some experience before you go off and go start the company that you've always been thinking about starting, which piece of advice do you actually take? Right? A lot of it depends on your situation, what you're considering, what skills and experience you actually have, and curiosity loops actually are this way of really thinking about how do you make your advice contextual.
text_ko: 문제는 그 조언이 악의적이라서가 아니라 맥락이 빠져 있어서예요. 그래서 누군가 '직장을 그만두고 꿈을 쫓아라'라거나 '일단 버티면서 경험을 쌓고 난 뒤에 창업해라'라고 하면, 어느 쪽 조언을 따라야 할까요? 많은 게 본인의 상황, 지금 고려하는 것들, 그리고 실제로 가진 스킬과 경험에 달려 있어요. 호기심 루프(curiosity loop)는 바로 조언을 어떻게 상황에 맞게 만들지 고민하는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 这些建议之所以不好，不是因为出发点不好，而是因为缺乏具体情境。比如有人跟你说辞职去追梦想，或者有人告诉你先熬着积累经验，等有了经验再去创业做你一直想做的公司，那你到底该听哪个建议呢？对吧？很大程度上取决于你的具体情况，你在考虑什么，你实际有什么技能和经验，而好奇心循环(curiosity loops)其实就是一种思考方式，帮你把建议变得更有针对性。
text_es: Y el problema no es que tengan malas intenciones, sino que les falta contexto. Entonces cuando alguien te dice "renuncia a tu trabajo y persigue tus sueños", o te dice "aguanta ahí y sigue echándole ganas, gana experiencia antes de irte a crear esa empresa en la que siempre has pensado", ¿cuál consejo sigues realmente? ¿No? Mucho depende de tu situación, lo que estés considerando, qué habilidades y experiencia tengas en realidad, y los bucles de curiosidad (curiosity loops) son precisamente esta forma de pensar en cómo hacer que tus consejos tengan contexto.
context: Lenny asks Ada about curiosity loops and why they're better than traditional advice-seeking. A curiosity loop is when you ask the same question to 10-15 people to gather diverse perspectives rather than relying on one person's opinion. Ada explains that most advice fails not because of bad intentions, but because it lacks context for your specific situation - what worked for one person may not apply to your circumstances.
vocabulary_highlights: well-intentioned, contextual, sit tight, grind through

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Decision Making
text: When I reflect back on what works across my early career, it really comes down in a nutshell to this career concept of explore and exploit. You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, how well it works, whether or not it fits for you. Or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep and then you're just trying to get more.
text_ko: 제 초반 커리어를 돌이켜보면, 결국 한마디로 정리하면 '탐색(explore)과 활용(exploit)'이라는 커리어 개념이에요. 어떤 때는 탐색 모드로, 모르는 게 많아서 이 일이 내가 좋아하는지, 잘 되는지, 나한테 맞는지 이것저것 시도해보는 시기예요. 반대로 활용 모드일 땐 이미 정말 깊고 풍부한 무언가를 찾았기 때문에 그걸 더 확장하고 더 많은 성과를 얻으려고 해요.
text_zh: 回头看我职业生涯初期什么管用，说白了就是一个概念：探索和深挖(explore and exploit)。你要么处在探索模式，面对一堆未知的东西，试试看自己喜不喜欢，效果怎么样，适不适合自己。要么就是在深挖，你已经找到了真正有价值、有深度的东西，然后就是想办法挖得更深。
text_es: Cuando pienso en lo que me funcionó al principio de mi carrera, al final todo se reduce a este concepto: explorar y explotar. O estás en modo explorador, donde tienes un montón de incógnitas y estás probando a ver si te gusta, qué tal funciona, si es lo tuyo o no. O estás explotando, donde ya encontraste algo que realmente vale la pena y tiene mucho potencial, y entonces simplemente tratas de sacarle el máximo provecho.
context: Lenny asks Ada what advice she has for early career professionals based on her rapid rise from entry-level at Microsoft to SVP at SurveyMonkey in seven years. Ada explains her framework of 'explore and exploit' - early in your career you should explore different roles and industries to find what you enjoy, then once you find something valuable, exploit it by going deep and building expertise in that area.
vocabulary_highlights: in a nutshell, bunch of unknowns, really rich and really deep

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Decision Making
text: And one of the big reasons why I think curiosity loops are really useful is that it really fights the fact that there's a lot of bad advice out there. And it's not bad because it's not well-intentioned, but it's bad because it's not contextual.
text_ko: 제가 호기심 루프(curiosity loop)가 정말 유용하다고 생각하는 큰 이유 중 하나는, 이게 세상에 널린 잘못된 조언들에 맞서는 데 도움이 되기 때문이에요. 그 조언들이 의도가 나쁘다기보다는 맥락이 없어서 문제가 되는 경우가 많거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得好奇心循环(curiosity loop)特别有用，主要原因之一就是能帮我们对付那些糟糕的建议。这些建议问题不在于出发点不好，而是缺乏具体情境。
text_es: Y una de las razones principales por las que creo que los bucles de curiosidad (curiosity loops) son súper útiles es que realmente combaten el hecho de que hay muchísimos malos consejos por ahí. Y no digo que sean malos porque la gente tenga mala fe, sino que el problema es que no tienen contexto.
context: Lenny asks Ada when to use curiosity loops versus just asking friends for advice. Ada explains that curiosity loops come in both heavyweight (structured email to 10+ people) and lightweight (casually asking the same question to multiple people over time) versions. She emphasizes that curiosity loops help combat bad advice, which isn't bad due to poor intentions but because it lacks context for your specific situation.

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Decision Making
text: I think that there are heavyweight and lightweight ways to use this. So the heavyweight way was what I just exemplified by saying, I sent an email and I made a doc. And on the other side, I had all of this really interesting and rich data. The lightweight way to do this is really just make it your ongoing theme of what you're curious about as you interact with people.
text_ko: 이걸 쓰는 데는 무거운 방식(heavyweight way)과 가벼운 방식(lightweight way)이 있다고 생각해요. 제가 방금 예로 든 무거운 방식은 이메일을 보내고 문서를 만들었다고 말한 그런 방식이고, 반면 거기에는 정말 흥미롭고 풍부한 데이터가 쌓여 있었어요. 가벼운 방식은 사람들과 대화할 때 무엇이 궁금한지 그걸 계속 관심을 두는 주제로 삼는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个方法有重量级和轻量级两种用法。重量级的做法就是我刚才举的例子，发邮件、做文档，然后收集到很多有意思的丰富数据。轻量级的做法其实就是把它当作一个持续的主题，平时和人打交道的时候，带着这种好奇心去了解。
text_es: Creo que hay maneras más pesadas y más ligeras de hacer esto. La manera pesada fue lo que acabo de ejemplificar diciendo, mandé un email e hice un documento. Y del otro lado, tenía toda esta información súper interesante y rica. La manera ligera de hacerlo es simplemente convertirlo en tu tema constante de qué te da curiosidad mientras interactúas con la gente.
context: Lenny asks Ada about the structure of curiosity loops and when to use them versus not. Ada describes two approaches: heavyweight involves sending structured emails to gather formal feedback on decisions, while lightweight means casually asking the same question to different people in regular conversations. She explains this helps you gather diverse perspectives on important decisions rather than relying on single sources of advice.
vocabulary_highlights: heavyweight and lightweight, exemplified, ongoing theme

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Decision Making
text: It's a terrible outcome to wake up one day and be late career and feel trapped because you have a certain lifestyle or a certain expectations of the people around you that you have to go work this job, but then you look at yourself in the mirror and you're not happy going in there. I think that's a terrible trap that we should all try to avoid as we navigate our career paths and find the thing that's most optimal for us, which is usually a mix of career success, but also meaningfulness and alignment in the work that we're doing with our values.
text_ko: 어느 날 문득 커리어 후반(late career)에 접어들어 ‘이 생활 수준 때문에, 주변 사람들의 기대 때문에 이 직장을 계속해야 해’라고 느끼며 갇혀 있다고 깨닫는 건 정말 끔찍해요. 그런데 거울을 봤을 때 출근하는 자신이 행복하지 않다면 더더욱 그래요. 저는 이런 함정은 커리어 경로(career paths)를 걸어가면서 모두가 피하려고 노력해야 한다고 생각해요. 보통 우리에게 가장 잘 맞는 건 커리어 성공(career success)뿐 아니라 일의 의미와 우리 가치관(values)에 부합하는 것이 섞여 있는 경우예요.
text_zh: 最怕的就是有一天醒来发现自己职业生涯都快到头了，却感觉被困住了，因为你已经习惯了某种生活方式，或者周围的人对你有某种期待，你不得不继续干这份工作。但是每天照镜子的时候，你根本不想去上班，一点都不开心。我觉得这是个很可怕的陷阱，我们在规划职业道路的时候都应该尽量避免。要找到最适合自己的那个平衡点，通常就是事业成功和工作的意义感要兼顾，做的事情要跟自己的价值观合拍。
text_es: Es terrible despertar un día ya avanzado en tu carrera y sentirte atrapado porque tienes cierto estilo de vida o porque la gente a tu alrededor espera que sigas trabajando en ese puesto, pero cuando te ves al espejo no estás contento de ir a trabajar. Creo que es una trampa horrible que todos deberíamos tratar de evitar mientras vamos construyendo nuestra carrera profesional y encontramos lo que mejor nos funciona, que normalmente es una mezcla de éxito profesional, pero también un trabajo que tenga sentido y que vaya de la mano con nuestros valores.
context: Ada is discussing the importance of making career decisions based on personal values rather than external expectations. She emphasizes that optimizing only for resume-building and impressive roles can lead to a trap where you wake up later in your career feeling unhappy despite external success. The key is finding work that balances career advancement with personal fulfillment and alignment with your core values.
vocabulary_highlights: late career, look at yourself in the mirror, navigate our career paths, most optimal

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Decision Making
text: My hot take is that for the vast majority of people, they probably do not need a coach. And what I often push people on is if you're thinking about getting a coach, which is usually an indication that they have a feeling of being stuck or they have a problem that they're trying to solve, I ask them, 'What are your goals when it comes to coaching? Roll it forward six months, what have you gotten done in your coaching experience.'
text_ko: 제 솔직한 의견은요, 대다수 사람들은 아마 코치가 필요하지 않을 거예요. 그리고 제가 자주 묻는 건, 코치를 고민하고 있다는 건 보통 막혀 있거나 해결하려는 문제가 있다는 신호인 경우가 많은데요, 그럴 때 저는 이렇게 물어봐요. "코칭으로 어떤 목표를 이루고 싶으세요? 6개월 뒤를 상상해 보세요. 코칭을 통해 무엇을 해냈나요?"
text_zh: 我的看法是，对大多数人来说，其实根本不需要教练。我经常会问那些想找教练的人——通常他们都是感觉卡住了或者遇到什么问题想解决——我会问他们："你找教练到底想达成什么目标？往前推六个月，你觉得通过教练指导能搞定什么事情？"
text_es: Mi opinión sin filtros es que la gran mayoría de la gente probablemente no necesita un coach. Y lo que siempre les pregunto a las personas cuando están pensando en contratar uno —que normalmente es señal de que se sienten estancadas o tienen algún problema que quieren resolver— es: "¿Qué esperas lograr con el coaching? Imagínate dentro de seis meses, ¿qué habrás conseguido con esta experiencia?"
context: Lenny asks Ada about when people should get an executive coach and whether everyone needs one. Ada gives her contrarian perspective that most people don't actually need coaches. She explains that before hiring a coach, people should consider alternatives like curiosity loops for advice, courses for learning skills, or building a community for support. She challenges people to clearly define their coaching goals and consider if there are better ways to achieve them.
vocabulary_highlights: hot take, push people on, roll it forward

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: Onboarding is the only part of your product experience that a hundred percent of people are ever going to touch. Good luck getting a hundred percent feature adoption of anything else in your product, right? But onboarding is the thing that you have to go through in order to use the product. It's also the first opportunity that you have as a company to deliver on the promise that you made out in the marketplace.
text_ko: 온보딩(onboarding)은 제품 경험에서 100%의 사용자가 꼭 거치게 되는 유일한 부분이에요. 제품의 다른 어떤 부분에서든 100%의 기능 채택(feature adoption)을 얻기란 거의 불가능하죠. 하지만 제품을 쓰려면 꼭 거쳐야 하는 게 온보딩이에요. 또 이는 회사가 시장에서 내세운 약속을 실제로 보여줄 수 있는 첫 번째 기회이기도 해요.
text_zh: 用户引导(onboarding)是你产品体验中唯一一个百分之百用户都会接触到的环节。你想让产品其他功能达到百分之百的使用率？基本不可能，对吧？但用户引导不一样，这是用户想用你产品就必须经历的过程。同时，这也是你们公司兑现市场承诺的第一次机会。
text_es: El onboarding es la única parte de la experiencia de tu producto que el cien por ciento de la gente va a usar sí o sí. A ver si logras que el cien por ciento de los usuarios adopte cualquier otra funcionalidad de tu producto, ¿no? Pero el onboarding es algo por lo que tienes que pasar obligatoriamente para poder usar el producto. También es la primera oportunidad que tienes como empresa para cumplir con la promesa que hiciste en el mercado.
context: Lenny asks Adam about the importance of onboarding as a growth lever. Adam explains why onboarding deserves significant attention from product and growth teams. He emphasizes that unlike other features which may have low adoption rates, every single user must go through onboarding to use your product. He frames onboarding as the critical moment where companies can either deliver on their marketing promises or disappoint new users.
vocabulary_highlights: good luck getting, deliver on the promise, out in the marketplace

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: I like to think of your brand is the promise that you're making and your product experience is your delivery of that promise. And those two things have to be in lockstep with each other, or you're going to have mismatched expectations and some really disappointed customers. So this is the first chance that a customer has to be really excited or really disappointed in what they thought they were getting. So don't mess that up.
text_ko: 저는 브랜드(brand)를 여러분이 하는 약속이라고 생각해요. 제품 경험(product experience)은 그 약속을 실제로 전달하는 방식이에요. 이 둘은 반드시 발을 맞춰야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 기대가 어긋나고 고객이 크게 실망하게 돼요. 고객이 자신이 받게 될 것에 대해 설레거나 실망하게 되는 첫 번째 기회가 바로 이 지점이에요. 그러니 이걸 망치지 마세요.
text_zh: 我觉得品牌就是你对客户的承诺，而产品体验就是你兑现这个承诺的过程。这两个必须完全同步，不然客户的期望就会落空，最后肯定会很失望。这是客户第一次真正体验你的产品，要么让他们特别惊喜，要么让他们特别失望。所以千万别搞砸了。
text_es: Me gusta pensar que tu marca es la promesa que estás haciendo y la experiencia del producto es cómo cumples esa promesa. Y estas dos cosas tienen que ir de la mano, si no, vas a tener expectativas que no coinciden y clientes súper decepcionados. Entonces esta es la primera oportunidad que tiene un cliente de emocionarse de verdad o llevarse una decepción tremenda con lo que pensaba que iba a recibir. Así que no la riegues.
context: Adam continues explaining why onboarding is such a crucial growth lever. He describes the relationship between marketing/branding and product experience, emphasizing that your brand creates expectations while your product must fulfill them. He warns that if these aren't aligned, you'll create disappointed customers. Adam stresses that onboarding is the first moment of truth where customers decide if the product matches what was promised.
vocabulary_highlights: in lockstep with each other, mismatched expectations, don't mess that up

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: One of the challenges of hiring a senior person is that they're all off writing newsletters and making podcast. Not that we know anybody who does that or anything, but... So I don't want to right now go back and work at a company again. I'm enjoying what I'm doing and so it's hard to get me, right? But also you don't want me, I think, when you're doing this for the first time.
text_ko: 시니어를 채용할 때의 어려움 중 하나가 다들 뉴스레터(newsletter) 쓰고 팟캐스트(podcast) 만들고 있어서 구하기가 어렵다는 거예요. 딱히 누굴 지목하려는 건 아니지만요... 그래서 저도 지금 당장 회사로 다시 들어가고 싶진 않아요. 지금 하는 일이 재미있어서 저를 데려오기 쉽지 않고요. 게다가 이런 걸 처음 해보는 분들한테는 저 같은 사람을 원하지도 않을 거라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 招聘高级人才的一个难点就是，这些人现在都跑去写newsletter、做播客去了。不是说我们认识什么这样的人啊，但是吧...所以我现在也不想回去给公司打工了。我现在做的事情挺享受的，所以你很难挖到我，对吧？但是话说回来，如果你是第一次创业的话，其实你也不会想要我这样的人。
text_es: Uno de los problemas de contratar a alguien con experiencia es que todos andan haciendo sus newsletters y podcasts. No es que conozcamos a nadie que haga eso ni nada, pero... La cosa es que yo ahora mismo no tengo ganas de volver a trabajar en una empresa. Me gusta lo que estoy haciendo y entonces es difícil que me convenzan, ¿no? Pero además creo que tampoco me querrían cuando están empezando con esto por primera vez.
context: Lenny asks Adam whether founders should focus on hiring up-and-coming growth people versus senior experienced leaders. Adam humorously points out that many senior growth practitioners (like himself and Lenny) have moved away from full-time roles to focus on content creation and consulting. He suggests that founders shouldn't necessarily want the most senior person anyway when building their first growth function.
vocabulary_highlights: they're all off writing, hard to get me, when you're doing this for the first time

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: If you're going to hire a junior person, the key is, how do you help them learn? And I think if you don't know what you're doing as the founder or the leader, it's hard. You're not going to be able to help them yourself. So you've got to be willing to invest in advisors like me, outside education, mentorship, coaching, otherwise, what's going to happen is that very driven, hungry and enthusiastic person is going to run through a lot of brick walls, which is great, except they're going to miss the fact that the door was standing right next to the wall that they just ran through and you're going to end up with a lot of bricks on the ground.
text_ko: 주니어(junior)를 채용할 거라면 핵심은 그 사람이 어떻게 배우도록 도와줄 거냐예요. 그리고 창업자(founder)나 리더(leader)로서 본인이 뭘 하고 있는지 모르면 그들을 직접 도와주기 힘들어요. 그래서 저 같은 어드바이저(advisor)나 외부 교육, 멘토링(mentorship), 코칭(coaching)에 기꺼이 투자할 준비가 돼 있어야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 의욕 넘치고 열정 있는 사람이 벽을 마구 부딪치며 달려가겠지만, 정작 그들이 부딪친 바로 옆에 문이 서 있었던 걸 못 보고 지나쳐 버려서 결국 바닥에 벽돌만 잔뜩 남게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你要招一个新人，关键是你怎么帮他们成长。我觉得如果你作为创始人或者领导自己都不太清楚怎么做，那就很难办了。你没法亲自去指导他们。所以你得舍得投资，找像我这样的顾问，或者外部培训、导师指导(mentorship)、教练服务(coaching)什么的。要不然会怎么样呢？那些很有冲劲、很hungry、很有热情的人就会到处撞墙，这种拼劲当然是好事，但问题是他们撞墙的时候，往往没注意到墙边上就有门，结果地上一堆砖头瓦片的。
text_es: Si vas a contratar a alguien junior, lo clave es: ¿cómo lo vas a ayudar a aprender? Y creo que si tú como fundador o líder no tienes claro lo que haces, se complica mucho. No vas a poder ayudarlos tú mismo. Entonces tienes que estar dispuesto a invertir en asesores como yo, capacitación externa, mentores, coaching... porque si no, lo que va a pasar es que esa persona tan ambiciosa, con tantas ganas y entusiasmo, se va a estar dando cabezazos contra la pared todo el tiempo. Y está bien, el problema es que no se va a dar cuenta de que la puerta estaba justo al lado de la pared contra la que se estuvo golpeando, y al final vas a terminar con un montón de ladrillos en el suelo.
context: Adam continues discussing the challenge of hiring junior growth people. He explains that if founders choose to hire someone less experienced, they must invest in that person's development through advisors, education, and mentorship. Without proper guidance, even the most motivated junior hire will make costly mistakes by trying to solve problems the hard way instead of finding easier solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: run through a lot of brick walls, the door was standing right next to the wall, end up with a lot of bricks on the ground

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: I actually think if you're doing it right, sometimes conversion should actually decrease a little bit. So you might actually have fewer people getting all the way through successfully, but I think that's okay because a lot of those people were probably not the right people for your product, which means they wouldn't have been engaged customers, they probably would have churned.
text_ko: 사실 제대로 하고 있다면 전환율(conversion)이 오히려 조금 낮아질 때도 있어요. 그래서 최종까지 성공적으로 도달하는 사람이 줄어들 수 있는데, 그건 괜찮아요. 그런 사람들 대부분은 원래 우리 제품에 맞는 사람들이 아니었을 가능성이 크거든요. 활성 고객(engaged customers)이 되지 못하고 결국 이탈(churn)했을 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果你做得对的话，转化率(conversion)有时候其实应该稍微降一点。可能真正走完整个流程的人会少一些，但我觉得这没关系，因为那些人本来就不是你产品的目标用户，也就是说他们不会是活跃用户，很可能最后还是会流失掉。
text_es: La verdad es que si lo estás haciendo bien, a veces la conversión debería bajar un poco. O sea, puede que tengas menos gente que complete todo el proceso exitosamente, pero creo que eso está bien porque muchos de esos probablemente no eran el cliente ideal para tu producto, lo que significa que no habrían sido usuarios comprometidos y seguramente se habrían dado de baja.
context: Lenny asks Adam how to think about the tradeoff between onboarding conversion and retention. Adam explains a counterintuitive insight about effective onboarding - sometimes it should actually convert fewer people overall. He argues that good onboarding acts as a filter, weeding out users who aren't a good fit for the product, which ultimately improves retention metrics even if conversion rates drop slightly.
vocabulary_highlights: if you're doing it right, getting all the way through, weeding out

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: When you're interviewing at a company, you are actually investing an even more scarce resource. You're investing your time. There is no way to get more time. We're all on a finite clock. You can always get more money. If you make a bad investment decision, 'Okay, we lost there.' Provided you didn't bankrupt yourself. Even if you did, you can climb out of bankruptcy. There are things that you can do, but time is fleeting.
text_ko: 회사에서 면접을 볼 때는 사실 훨씬 더 귀한 자원을 투자하는 거예요. 바로 시간이에요. 시간을 더 얻을 방법은 없어요. 우리 모두에게는 한정된 시간이 있어요. 돈은 언제든 더 벌 수 있죠. 투자 결정을 잘못해 손해를 봐도 ‘아, 거기서 졌구나’ 하고 넘길 수 있어요. 파산하지 않았다면요. 설사 파산을 했다 해도 다시 일어설 방법은 있어요. 하지만 시간은 금방 흘러가요.
text_zh: 面试的时候，其实你投入的是更稀缺的资源——时间。时间这个东西是没法增加的，我们每个人的时间都是有限的。钱可以再赚，投资失误了就失误了，"好吧，这次亏了"。只要没破产就行。就算真破产了，也能东山再起，总有办法。但时间不等人，过去就过去了。
text_es: Cuando estás en una entrevista de trabajo, en realidad estás invirtiendo un recurso aún más escaso. Estás invirtiendo tu tiempo. No hay manera de conseguir más tiempo. Todos tenemos el reloj corriendo en nuestra contra. Dinero siempre puedes conseguir más. Si tomas una mala decisión de inversión, "Bueno, ahí perdimos." Siempre y cuando no te hayas arruinado completamente. Y aunque así fuera, de la bancarrota se puede salir. Hay cosas que se pueden hacer, pero el tiempo se nos va volando.
context: Adam is explaining his PMF framework for evaluating companies to work at (People, Mission, Financials). He draws an analogy between investment due diligence and job searching, arguing that candidates should be just as rigorous when choosing employers. He emphasizes that when you take a job, you're investing something more valuable than money - your time - which cannot be recovered if you make a poor choice.
vocabulary_highlights: even more scarce resource, finite clock, climb out of bankruptcy, time is fleeting

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: One of the biggest pieces of advice I'm giving to people that are like, "How should we adjust our marketing with the economic changes and things like that?" I was like, "Start by assuming you no longer have product market fit, because you had product market fit in a different market." It's a different market now, so you have to start over.
text_ko: 요즘 경제 상황이 바뀌는데 마케팅을 어떻게 조정해야 하냐고 물어보는 분들에게 제가 자주 드리는 가장 큰 조언 중 하나는 이거예요. 일단 '제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)'이 없어졌다고 가정해 보세요. 이전에 적합성이 있었던 건 다른 시장에서였거든요. 지금은 시장 자체가 달라졌으니 처음부터 다시 시작해야 해요.
text_zh: 很多人问我"经济环境变了，我们的营销策略该怎么调整？"我就跟他们说，"首先你得假设你现在没有产品市场匹配度(product market fit)了，因为你之前的产品市场匹配度(product market fit)是在不同的市场环境下。现在市场变了，你得重新来过。"
text_es: Uno de los mejores consejos que le doy a la gente que me pregunta "¿Cómo deberíamos ajustar nuestro marketing con los cambios económicos y todo eso?" les digo: "Empiecen asumiendo que ya no tienen product market fit, porque tenían product market fit en un mercado diferente." Ahora es otro mercado, así que hay que empezar de cero.
context: At the opening of the podcast, Adam shares advice he's giving to companies about adjusting their marketing during economic downturns. He emphasizes that when market conditions change dramatically, companies should reassess their fundamentals rather than just tweaking tactics. His key insight is that product-market fit isn't permanent - it exists within specific market conditions, and when those conditions shift significantly, companies need to re-establish fit rather than assume their previous success will continue.
vocabulary_highlights: adjust our marketing, product market fit, start over

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: So, I think generally the whole suite of skills that you develop in improv are pretty applicable, right? Because you are getting comfortable on your feet with change, with teamwork, building off of each other, experimenting, trying new things, a little bit of everything.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 전반적으로 즉흥연기(improv)로 기르는 스킬셋(skill set)이 실제로 꽤 유용하다고 생각해요. 변화에 발빠르게 대응하고, 팀워크를 발휘하고, 서로의 아이디어를 받아 발전시키고, 실험해보고 새로 시도해보는 등 이것저것 조금씩 해보는 데 익숙해지거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得即兴表演(improv)里学到的那套技能，基本上都能用得上，对吧？因为你会习惯随机应变，学会团队合作，互相配合，敢于尝试，什么都会接触一点。
text_es: Yo creo que en general todas las habilidades que desarrollas con la improvisación se pueden aplicar bastante bien, ¿no? Porque te acostumbras a reaccionar sobre la marcha ante los cambios, a trabajar en equipo, a construir sobre las ideas de otros, a experimentar, a probar cosas nuevas, un poco de todo.
context: Lenny asks Adam what he's learned from improv that has helped him in his work. Adam explains how improv training develops multiple business-relevant skills simultaneously. He describes how improv teaches adaptability, collaboration, and experimentation - all crucial skills for working in fast-paced tech environments where change is constant and teams need to build on each other's ideas.
vocabulary_highlights: suite of skills, on your feet, building off of each other

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: So, if someone's starting a scene and they're clearly watching television and clicking through the channels and I walk up and just say like, "Oh, you're watching TV, cool." That's a yes statement. I'm not denying what they did. But if I come up and say like, "Oh cool, you're watching TV. Is that an Alf episode? I haven't seen Alf since I was a kid. It reminds me this one time I actually ate my own cat."
text_ko: 그러니까 누군가 장면을 시작하려고 하고 분명 TV를 보면서 채널을 넘기고 있을 때 제가 다가가서 "아, TV 보시는군요. 좋네요."라고 하면 그건 그들이 한 말을 인정하는 거예요. 그걸 부정하는 게 아니죠. 그런데 제가 다가가서 "오, TV 보시는군요. 그거 알프(Alf) 편인가요? 전 어릴 때 이후로 알프 본 적이 없네요. 이거 보니까 옛날에 제가 진짜 제 고양이를 먹었던 일이 생각나네요."라고 말하면요.
text_zh: 所以，如果有人开始一个场景，他们明显在看电视换台，我走过去说"哦，你在看电视，不错啊。"这就是肯定性回应(yes statement)。我没有否定他们在做的事。但如果我走过去说"哦不错，你在看电视。这是《阿尔夫》那一集吗？我从小时候就没看过《阿尔夫》了。这让我想起有一次我真的把自己家的猫给吃了。"
text_es: Entonces, si alguien está empezando una escena y claramente está viendo tele cambiando canales, y yo me acerco y le digo algo como "Ah, estás viendo tele, qué bien." Eso es una declaración de sí. No estoy negando lo que hicieron. Pero si me acerco y digo algo como "Ah qué bien, estás viendo tele. ¿Eso es un episodio de Alf? No he visto Alf desde que era niño. Me recuerda a esa vez que me comí a mi propio gato."
context: Adam explains the improv concept of "the gift of details" and how it applies to business communication. He contrasts generic acknowledgment with specific, detailed responses that give others more to work with. In improv, providing specific details like referencing the TV show Alf creates more opportunities for scene development. Adam argues this principle applies to business conversations - giving specific details opens up more productive discussions than vague responses.
vocabulary_highlights: the gift of details, yes statement, clicking through the channels

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: And if you approach it with that "Yes, and...", it's often still true. It's like, oh, both of these things can be true at once. You could have a different goal than I have, or you have a system problem local to you that is important to you and it's not important to me. That's okay, both things can exist.
text_ko: '예스 앤(Yes, and...)' 방식으로 접근하면, 그게 사실인 경우가 많아요. 즉, 두 가지가 동시에 맞을 수 있다는 거예요. 상대방이 저와 다른 목표를 가질 수도 있고, 혹은 그쪽에만 있는 시스템 문제(system problem)가 있어서 그게 그분에게는 중요한데 저한테는 아닐 수도 있어요. 괜찮아요, 두 가지가 동시에 존재할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 如果你用"是的，而且..."这种思路去看问题，往往都没错。就是说，这些事情可以同时都对。你的目标可能跟我不一样，或者你那边有个系统问题对你很重要，但对我来说不重要。这都没关系，两种情况都可以存在。
text_es: Y si lo abordas con esa mentalidad de "Sí, y además...", muchas veces sigue siendo válido. Es como, ah, las dos cosas pueden ser ciertas a la vez. Tú puedes tener un objetivo diferente al mío, o tienes un problema en tu área que para ti es importante pero para mí no tanto. Y está bien, las dos cosas pueden coexistir.
context: Lenny asks for examples of how Adam uses the improv principle "Yes, and..." in actual business situations. Adam describes applying this approach when working with cross-functional teams, specifically city teams at Uber. Rather than dismissing different perspectives or goals as wrong, he explains how accepting that multiple viewpoints can be simultaneously valid leads to better collaboration and solutions, especially when different teams have different local constraints or priorities.
vocabulary_highlights: Yes, and, cross-functional, both things can exist

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: But brand spanking new channels, I don't know, they rarely work or are worth the effort early that you hope that they will be.
text_ko: 근데 새로 생긴 채널(new channels)은, 글쎄요, 초반에는 잘 안 통하거나 기대만큼의 성과가 나지 않아서 공들일 가치가 없는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 但是那些全新的渠道，我觉得吧，一开始很少能达到你期望的效果，或者说前期投入的精力跟回报不太成正比。
text_es: Pero los canales completamente nuevos, no sé, casi nunca funcionan o valen la pena al principio como uno espera que lo hagan.
context: Lenny asks Adam what percentage of the time emerging marketing channels actually work out. Adam explains that while there are different types of "emerging" opportunities - like existing platforms adding new features versus completely new platforms - truly new channels rarely justify the early investment. He estimates only about 5% of emerging channels work, suggesting companies focus on proven channels first before experimenting with unproven ones.
vocabulary_highlights: brand spanking new, rarely work, worth the effort

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: And hopefully you do, or it's pretty close to it and you just have to adjust a couple things, and you could be right back on track. But if you just assume you need to launch a new channel to fix this problem, you're going to be wrong, because your entire customer base changed, not just the next 10% of customers that you're looking for.
text_ko: 다행히도 이미 그러거나 거의 그런 상태여서 몇 가지만 조정하면 바로 다시 궤도에 오를 수 있어요. 그런데 이 문제를 해결하려고 무조건 새 채널(channel)을 런칭(launch)해야 한다고 생각하면 틀려요. 당신이 찾으려는 다음 10%의 고객만 바뀐 게 아니라 전체 고객층(customer base)이 바뀌었기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 希望你能做到这一点，或者已经很接近了，只需要调整几个地方，就能重新回到正轨。但如果你觉得开个新渠道就能解决问题，那就想错了，因为你整个客户群体都变了，不只是你要找的下一批10%的客户。
text_es: Y ojalá sea así, o que al menos esté cerca y solo tengas que ajustar un par de cosas, y ya puedas volver al buen camino. Pero si simplemente asumes que necesitas lanzar un nuevo canal para arreglar este problema, te vas a equivocar, porque lo que cambió fue toda tu base de clientes, no solo el próximo 10% de clientes que estás buscando.
context: Adam continues his earlier advice about reassessing product-market fit during economic changes. He warns against the common mistake of trying to solve fundamental market shifts by simply adding new marketing channels. His point is that when market conditions change dramatically, the entire customer base and their needs may have shifted, requiring companies to revisit their core value proposition rather than just expanding their marketing reach.
vocabulary_highlights: right back on track, launch a new channel, entire customer base changed

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: And I think still there's just a lot of fundamental things that marketers think about that are stuck in that world, because most haven't had to grow through the true growth of a business that's just being established today.
text_ko: 저는 아직도 많은 마케터들이 그 기존 방식에 머물러 기본적인 것들에서 벗어나지 못한다고 생각해요. 대부분은 요즘 새로 시작하는 비즈니스가 실제로 성장해가는 '진짜 성장'(true growth)을 겪어본 적이 없거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得现在还是有很多营销人员的思维模式还停留在过去那套做法上，主要是因为他们大多数人都没有经历过从零开始做一个新业务、真正从头开始增长的过程。
text_es: Y creo que todavía hay muchas cosas básicas en las que piensan los de marketing que siguen atascadas en esa mentalidad, porque la mayoría no ha tenido que pasar por el crecimiento real de un negocio que se está estableciendo hoy en día.
context: Adam discusses the evolution needed in marketing leadership, explaining his concept of the "Growth CMO." He argues that traditional marketing approaches were developed for different eras when product development cycles were much longer and marketing owned different aspects of the business. He contends that many marketers still operate with outdated frameworks because they haven't experienced the rapid iteration cycles and integrated product-marketing approach required by modern software companies.
vocabulary_highlights: stuck in that world, grow through, just being established today
